author: Emma Thomasson
title: Levi’s hopes to reverse denim decline with stretch, vintage | Americas
text:
Levi Strauss. Picture: BLOOMBERG ROME — Levi Strauss & Co, the company that invented blue jeans in 1873, is hoping to revive its business by launching a new women’s range with more stretch to compete with yoga pants, tapping into vintage fashion and pushing more accessories.
Privately owned by the descendants of the family of Levi Strauss, the firm is still the world’s biggest denim brand ahead of VF Corp’s Wrangler’s and Lee labels. But it has been in decline for years as competition has mounted from luxury, discount and mass fashion brands, compounded by the rising popularity of sportswear as a casual alternative to jeans.
James Curleigh, president of the Levi’s brand, said Levi’s was seeking to connect with younger consumers by adjusting its designs to their tastes, by adding more stretch and tapering legs as well as tapping into the music scene, including teaming up with singer Alicia Keys for the launch of its women’s collection in July.
"Our women’s business has never been stronger than it is right now," Mr Curleigh told Reuters at the World Retail Congress.
"It is back. It’s in growth mode. No-one traded their entire wardrobe for yoga pants.
"We know that if someone goes into a pair of Levi’s they tend to stay with us for a really long time, but we have to make that initial reconnection," he said.
Total sales of jeans in the US fell 5% in the year ending May 2015, data from information group NPD showed. But they increased 2% among the group of 18-to 34-year-old consumers dubbed "millennials" by marketers.
The size of the global jeans market could grow to almost $143bn in 2019 from nearly $102bn in 2014, data firm Euromonitor predicts, with most growth coming from developing markets. The global sportswear market is almost three times as big.
As it seeks a bigger market share, Levi’s wants to win customers by promoting the durability of its products.
It is also responding to growing consumer interest in environmental issues by working on ways to cut water use, improve recycling techniques and encourage the repair and resale of old jeans as vintage styles become fashionable again.
"The best that you ever look in a piece of fast fashion is the first time you wear it. It has this sort of half-life," Mr Curleigh said.
"We’d rather people have fewer products, but better products from Levi’s.
"What we’re promising with a pair of Levi’s, or anything from Levi’s, is the best you’re going to look is one, two, three, five, 10 years in the future.
"My son, I know, will want this jacket," he said, fingering a classic-style off-white trucker jacket.
That sentiment chimes with the brand’s "Live in Levi’s" slogan and a site launched in 2014 to collect fan’s stories, pictures and videos about their favourite jeans.
Levi’s sales fell 6% to $1.012bn in the quarter to May 31, although they rose 1% on a constant currency basis, helped by growth from its stores in Europe and Asia.
Noting that denim only makes up about 6% of an average wardrobe, Mr Curleigh said Levi’s is selling more belts, tops, footwear, socks and underwear, which still only make up 20% of its sales but are performing better than jeans.
"Every one of our categories outside denim is growing faster than denim but we are still growing denim so ‘protect the core, expand for more’ is working," he said.
Reuters
